desc: Based on PhpStorm deck from here: shared deck page. Intent is to create generic deck for Intellij platform shrotcuts, and then supplement it when needed with specific shortcuts for specific products.
name: Software::Intellij Platform Keyboard Shortcuts

note_models.name: Basic [reversed, extra, source]
Cloze [extra, source]

fields: Quick documentation lookup for code under coursor (also works in autocompletion window).
Brief info about code element under mouse cursor.
Ctrl + hover mouse over code element
Override methods (opens window that allows you to select methods you want to override)
Implement methods of a base class
Syntax aware selection in the editor.

It selects a word at the caret and then selects expanding areas of the source code. For example, it may select a method name, then the expression that calls this method, then the whole statement, then the containing block, etc.
Decrease current selection to previous state (in the context of sythax aware selection).
Shift + Alt + L/Mac: Cmd + Alt + L
Duplicate current line or selected block.
Smart line join (HTML and JavaScript only)
Smart line split (HTML and JavaScript only)
Start new line (creates new line under the current one and moves your coursour there)
Toggle case for word at caret or selected block.
Allows you to choose from stuff copied, while IDE was open.
Ctrl + Shift + F/R (On mac also Ctrl and not Cmd)
Show usages (of a class, method or variable) across the project
Go to line in current file

Besides recent files, you can bring up results of the usage searches you have performed recently. To do that, use the same Ctrl+E shortcut with the Find tool window having the focus, and select the desired find usages result from the Recent Find Usages popup.
Navigate back/forward (works for switching between the files, going to definitions, selections, etc)

Ctrl + Alt + Left/Right or Back and Forward mouse buttons.
Mac (custom ones): Ctrl + Shift + Left/Right
Navigate to last edit location (brings you back to the last place where you made changes in the code)
Pressing Ctrl+Shift+Backspace a few times moves you deeper into your changes history.
Go to declaration (of a class, method or variable)
Ctrl + B or Ctrl + Left Mouse button Click
Go to previous/next method in the editor
Copy file (when selected in project view)
Introduce Variable Refactoring from expression. (Extract variable)

This expression may even be incomplete or contain errors. 
It also can select a likely expression when no text is selected.
Refactor This (shows all refactorings available in the current context)
View recent changes to the project
Find any action, symbol, or setting
Switch between tabs; show tool window
Insert Live Template (commonly used code constructs like: comprehensions, for loops, property functions, main, super functions, etc).

The shortcuts such as Ctrl+Q (View | Quick Documentation), Ctrl+P (View | Parameter Info), Ctrl+B (Navigate | Declaration) and others can be used {{c1::not only in the editor}} but in {{c2::the code completion popup list}} as well.
When in the Go to Class, Go to Symbol, or Go to File popup, you can ease the search by filtering the lookup list with the help of the {{c1::"camel words"}} prefixes.

Drag your mouse pointer while keeping Win + Alt (or Control+Alt+Shift) pressed
Mac: Central mouse button + drag
or Alt + click and drag
Ctrl + C while nothing is selected
Run an inspection on the current file
If there are too many run/debug configurations of the same type, you can {{c1::group them into folders}}, and thus distinguish them visually.
Win + Alt (Mac: just Alt), click the left mouse button at the desired position in the editor
Move File (when selected in project view)
Stop whatever is running right now
Jump between compiler error messages or search operation results. (Next/Previous Occurance)
Ctrl + Alt + ↑/ Ctrl + Alt + ↓ (Also Ctrl and not Cmd on Mac)
Hide active or last active window
Toggle Favorites panel (bookmarks, breakpoints are also displayed)
Toggle Run panel (run current configuration, see the results)
Toggle 'ToDo' panel (Shows the occurrences of todo comments across the project)
Toggle 'Structure' panel. Displays structure of the current class or file (methods, fields, etc)
Toggle Language Console panel. Language console is opened in current working directory and has support for autocompletion/showing variables/etc.
Inline variable (for all usages or the selected one) and optionally remove the variable
Display the diff between two files (or directories) in the project (or file in the project vs external file).

IntelliJ IDEA has a built-in Diff viewers for code, jar files, revisions and even images. To invoke it, select any pair of files and press ⌘D.
If you have selected a single file, the IDE will prompt you to select the one to compare to. 

To quickly compare active editor with Clipboard, choose View | Compare with Clipboard.

1) Start typing.
2) Press ⌃⇧Space or choose Code | Completion | SmartType from the main menu.
The most suitable suggestion for the current context is highlighted.

Smart completion based on type
Smart code completion filters the suggestions list and shows only the types applicable to the current context.
Smart completion is useful in situations when it is possible to determine the appropriate type:
*In the right part of assignment statements 
*In variable initializers 
*In return statements 
*In the list of arguments of a method call 
*After the new keyword in an object declaration
*In chained expressions

For chained expressions, suggestions are sorted by how frequently they are used in the project. When any of the suggested method calls takes an argument that is not yet available in the context, after you select it the IDE defines a local variable of the required type.

Invoke statements completion

Statements completion enables you to create syntactically correct code constructs. It inserts the necessary syntax elements (parentheses, braces, semicolons etc.) and gets you in a position where you can start typing the next statement.

Complete a method declaration
Start typing a method declaration and press ⇧⌘⏎ after the opening parenthesis:
This will create an entire construct of a method, the caret resting inside the method body:
---

Complete a code construct
Start typing a code construct and press ⇧⌘⏎:
IntelliJ IDEA automatically completes the construct and adds the required punctuation, and the caret is placed at the next editing position:

---
Wrap a method call argument
Type an expression, for example
"test"
Type a method call. When println gets the focus in the suggestion list, select it with ⇧⌘⏎:
The resulting code will look like the following:
System.out.println("test");

Postfix code completion helps you reduce backward caret jumps as you write code. It allows you to transform an already typed expression to a different one based on a postfix you type after the dot, the type of expression, and its context.

Transform a statement with a postfix

Type an expression and then type a postfix after a dot, for example .if:
fun foo(x: Boolean) { x.if }

The initial expression gets wrapped with an if statement:
fun foo(x: Boolean) { if (x) { } }

Type Migration

The Type Migration refactoring allows you to automatically change a member type (e.g. from integer to string), and data flow dependent type entries, like method return types, local variables, parameters etc. across the entire project. It also lets automatically convert variable or method return type between arrays and collections. If any conflicts are found IntelliJ IDEA warns you about them.

Example
f: int -> String

Before
int f; 
void bar(int i) {} 
void foo() { bar(f); }

After
String f; 
void bar(String i) {} 
void foo() { bar(f); }

The Wrap Return Value refactoring allows you to select a method, and either create a wrapper class for its return values, or use an existing, compatible wrapper class. All returns from the method selected will be appropriately wrapped, and all calls to the method will have their returns unwrapped.
Wrapping a method's returns are useful, if your design changes in such a way that you want a method to return more information than originally planned. After wrapping, the wrapper class can be extended, allowing more data to be returned from the method. Also, it is common to wrap primitive return values, thus allowing interface and implementation to be decoupled as needed.

Before
class Order { String customer; String getCustomer() { return customer; } }
After
class Order { String customer; Customer getCustomer() { } } 
class Customer { String id; Customer(String id) { this.id=id; } }
Encloses the selected block of code in a block comment
To uncomment a commented block press ⌃⇧/ anywhere inside it.
Navigate in the currently edited file. (Navigate | File Structure).
This shows the list of members of the current class. Select an element you want to navigate to and press the Enter key or the F4 key.
When using {{c1::Code Completion}}, you can accept the currently highlighted selection in the popup list with the {{c2::period character (.), comma (,), semicolon (;), space and other characters.}}
The selected name is automatically entered in the editor followed by the entered character.
Move method parameters (both declaration and invocation)
Moreover, it's possible to propagate such a move in a method declaration to the method invocations - just immediately after move press ⌥⏎, and choose Apply signature change.
Add several cursors to your editor (via keyboard).
Press Alt twice and hold the key (Ctrl if not on Mac), and then press the arrow keys.
Use {{c1::IntelliJIDEA’s External Tools}} to {{c2::add shortcuts to frequently used commands}}

The Problem
IDE users normally prefer to have frequently used actions as buttons or shortcuts instead of running them manually every time (generally through the terminal), resulting in small productivity losses.
 
A Solution
Setup external tools for the frequently used commands so they can be ran directly through IntelliJIDEA, based on context.
In order to do so, open Preferences | Tools | External Tools and click the + button to add a new tool configuration.
 
A Simple Example
Brazil Build Package
Program: brazil-build
Arguments: leave it blank
Working directory: $ModuleFileDir$
Show in: Project views
Switch between open code panels sequentially
Move open file to the opposite panel

AceJump: The main AceAction.
Type any string in the editor, followed by one of highlighted tags, to jump its position.
AceJump: Target Mode. Once Target Mode is activated, jumping to a tag will select an entire word. Target Mode can also be activated directly by pressing the shortcut for AceTargetAction
AceJump: Line Mode - target the beginning, first non-whitespace characters, and end of every line in the editor). Then jump to one by completing the tag.
Press Alt+; followed {{c1::by → to target the last}}, {{c2::← to target the first,}} or {{c3::↑, to target the first non-whitespace}} characters of every line in the editor.
AceJump: Hold down Shift when typing the last tag character
Select all text from the current cursor position to that destination.
Jump to the next (or nearest) result.
AceJump - Start in a word mode (hint for every word is displayed)
